title: Triggers and Events
learning_objectives: Understand the Triggers and Events concept in SQL

definition.concept_explanation: Triggers and Events is an important SQL concept for working with databases.

examples.title: SQL Example 1
examples.sql: CREATE TRIGGER vendors_before_update BEFORE UPDATE ON users FOR EACH ROW SET NEW.vendor_ state = UPPER (NEW.vendor_ state);

examples.title: SQL Example 2
examples.sql: create triggers and events 481 A trigger that validates line products amounts when updating an orders DELIMITER// CREATE TRIGGER invoices_before_update BEFORE UPDATE ON orders FOR EACH ROW BEGIN DECLARE sum_ line_ products amount DECIMAL (9,2);

examples.title: SQL Example 3
examples.sql: SELECT SUM (line_ item_amount) INTO sum_ line_ item_amount FROM invoice_line_ products WHERE invoice_id = NEW.invoice_ id;

common_mistakes.title: Syntax error
common_mistakes.why_it_happens: Typo in SQL keyword. The correct keyword is FROM, not FORM.

common_mistakes.title: Missing semicolon
common_mistakes.error_message: Some databases require semicolons to end statements
common_mistakes.why_it_happens: While some SQL implementations are lenient, it's best practice to end statements with semicolons.
common_mistakes.key_takeaway: Always end SQL statements with a semicolon
